Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Microscope-based, Spectrofluorometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Benedictine University faculty and student researchers will use the spectrofluorometer/microscope system to initiate projects that involve the detection of rapid changes in the fluorescence state of molecules in response to their chemical environments. This work allows researchers to investigate contemporary issues in the fields of physiology, molecular biology, and biochemistry by using high-tech instrumentation to acquire real-time measures of cell physiology and signaling without damaging the cells. Undergraduates, including those from underrepresented backgrounds, have the opportunity to participate in research and gain a solid foundation for careers or graduate school. This work also supports an internship program involving both pre-service and K-8 in-service teachers, enabling them to learn first-hand the excitement of investigation and achievement in science that they then bring to the next generation of students.

Researchers in the biology and chemistry departments at Benedictine University will use the spectrofluorescence system to advance their scientific research programs in four biochemistry projects: (1) Regulation of paracellular permeability and ion transport in epithelial cells; (2) Anti-estrogenic effects of metals in osteoclasts; (3) Structure/function properties of G-protein signaling; (4) Fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET)-monitored phage display system for the targeting of signal proteins. By promoting interdisciplinary work at Benedictine, these projects together improve the competencies of students by providing access to classical and state-of-the-art techniques in cellular biology and chemistry, such as in the capstone biochemistry and molecular biology cell laboratory. Students gain first-hand experiences and opportunities to conduct original science, with extensive planning, data analysis and reporting, that can potentially lead to new discoveries. The projects contribute to the integration of science processes and quantitative reasoning with Benedictine's curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Benedictine University faculty and student researchers have utilized the spectrofluorometer/microscope system to work on projects that involve the detection of rapid changes in the fluorescence state of molecules in response to their chemical environments. We investigated contemporary issues in the fields of physiology, molecular biology, and biochemistry by using high-tech instrumentation to acquire real-time measures of cell physiology and signaling without damaging the cells. The results of the experiments conducted with this equipment have added a wealth of information in the areas of cell signaling, particularly in bile acid signaling and regulation of ion transport. Further, the acquisition of state-of-the-art equipment has stimulated student interest in research and provided them with valuable hands-on experience in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (BMB) laboratory courses, which is one of the major goals of the institution. The deeper integration of research and education with the projects made possible by this acquisition has increased the independence of students and influenced them to continue their higher education and become life-long learners. Additionally, by promoting interactions between the scientific disciplines, these projects increased students’ awareness of the interdisciplinary nature of science.  Undergraduates, including those from underrepresented backgrounds, have been given the opportunity to participate in research and gain a solid foundation for careers or graduate school. This includes a first generation college student from the PI’s research lab who attended a National conference (Experimental Biology, 2018) to present her research work and won national awards.  She is now applying to doctoral programs in physiology to pursue scientific research.  Another student who is an underrepresented minority and first generation college student who is a researcher in the PI’s research lab is the recipient of the American Physiological Society’s STRIDE fellowship.  These opportunities would not have been possible had it not been for the well-equipped laboratory facility that was made possible by the NSF-MRI grant.

 

Researchers in the biology and chemistry departments at Benedictine University used the spectrofluorescence system to advance their scientific research programs in the following areas: (1) Regulation of paracellular permeability and ion transport in epithelial cells. This system is used to examine the mechanisms by which excess luminal bile acids—due to bile acid malabsorption (BAM)—alter tight junction permeability, and to trace the movement of bile acids across the epithelium in real time. This will facilitate the understanding of excess fluid loss attributed to BAM and enables improvements to methods for tracing molecules without the use of radioactivity. (2) Structure/function properties of bile acid signaling. The availability of the instrument has made real-time measurements of intracellular calcium a reality and has helped us tease out the differences in intracellular signaling pathway of various bile acids and identify the molecular mechanisms behind the yin and yang in bile acid action. Bile acid diarrhea is seen in one-third of patients with inflammatory intestinal diseases and understanding the mechanism of bile acid action will help design new therapeutic strategies. (3) Anti-estrogenic effects of metals in osteoclast. This research examined mechanisms by which cadmium caused bone loss, monitoring the dose-dependent effect of cadmium in intracellular calcium by the spectrofluorescence system.  Thus, by promoting interdisciplinary work at Benedictine, together these projects improved the competencies of students by providing access to classical and state-of-the-art techniques in cell and molecular biology. Students gained experience with extensive planning, data analysis, critical analysis, and reporting, and participated in first-hand experiences and opportunities to conduct original science that has potential translational capability.  The data has been disseminated via oral and poster presentations by students in the PI and co-PI’s laboratory, in local, regional and national conferences and have received the recognition of outstanding undergraduate research in most occasions. The PI has also published the data collected using the instrument in reputed journals resulting in three publications already and and couple more in preparation.
